headline.main: Bloomberg and Thompson Spar in First Mayoral Debate

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN and MICHAEL BARBARO

docs.abstract: Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg squared off during the first of two mayoral debates, held at El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem.
docs.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:45 p.m. | Tonight was the first of two hourlong televised debates between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. Mr. Thompson is running as a Democrat; Mr. Bloomberg as Republican and independent. City Room live-blogged the debate, sponsored by the city's Campaign Finance Board and held at El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem. Dominic Carter of NY1 News moderated the debate. Updates are below, in reverse chronological order.
docs.snippet: Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg squared off during the first of two mayoral debates, held at El Museo del Barrio in East Harlem.

headline.main: Michelle Obama Offers More Healthy Food Tips

docs.abstract: The first lady offered some kitchen remedies for Americans to try to reduce their caloric intake.
docs.lead_paragraph: First Lady Michelle Obama urged Americans on Tuesday to lead healthier, more active lives by embracing "a drumbeat of small changes" in their day-to-day routines.
docs.snippet: The first lady offered some kitchen remedies for Americans to try to reduce their caloric intake.

docs.lead_paragraph: Children spending just over a dollar a day managed to buy an array of high-calorie snacks, researchers said.

headline.main: Current Health Care Legislation Will Not Control Medical Costs, Experts Warn

docs.abstract: Health policy experts warn that the current legislation pending in Congress will not do enough to rein in medical costs.
docs.lead_paragraph: With Democrats increasingly confident that they can pass major health care legislation this year, some of the nation's foremost experts are warning that the emerging bills do not do enough quickly to tamp down soaring medical costs - the biggest problem facing the majority of Americans, who already have insurance.
docs.snippet: Health policy experts warn that the current legislation pending in Congress will not do enough to rein in medical costs.

headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE
headline.main: Soaring Costs Remain a Bugaboo In Experts' Eyes

docs.abstract: Some of nation's foremost experts say emerging health care legislation does not do enough quickly to tamp down soaring medical costs, biggest problem facing majority of Americans who already have insurance; urge adjusting legislation to more aggressively reshape health system from one that overly rewards quantity of care to one that promotes high-quality, cost-efficient treatment; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: With Democrats increasingly confident that they can pass major health care legislation this year, some of the nation's foremost experts are warning that the emerging bills do not do enough quickly to tamp down soaring medical costs -- the biggest problem facing the majority of Americans, who already have insurance. As Congress prepares for heated floor debate (the Senate Finance Committee is expected to approve its bill on Tuesday), the experts, including policy analysts, hospital executives and current and former health officials, say lawmakers must make crucial changes.
